title: David Roderick, U.S. Steel CEO Who Slashed Costs and Diversified, Dies at 95
text:
David M. Roderick, who as chief executive of U.S. Steel Corp. in the 1980s closed scores of inefficient plants and diversified rapidly into oil and gas, died Saturday at his home in Latrobe, Pa., near Pittsburgh. A World War II Marine veteran who trained as an accountant, Mr. Roderick was 95.

U.S. Steel, created in 1901 by a merger of steel interests controlled by J.P. Morgan and Andrew Carnegie, long dominated one of the nation’s core industries. By the time Mr. Roderick became chairman and CEO in 1979, however, it was burdened...
description: U.S. Steel was reeling from foreign competition when David Roderick became CEO in 1979. The Marine veteran closed scores of inefficient plants and bought Marathon Oil and other energy assets. He died Saturday at age 95.
